case_name: Navnit Lal C. Javeri v. Income-tax Officer

facts.text: Appeal is Civil Appeal No. 45 of 1964 from Bombay High Court judgment dated July 30, 1962 in Special Civil Application No. 69 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 45 of1964. Appeal from the judgment and order dated July 30, 1962, of the Bombay High Court in Special Civil Application No. 69 of 1962.

facts.text: Appellant Navnit Lal C. Javeri filed writ petition in Bombay High Court challenging validity of section 12(1B) read with s. 2(6A)(e) of Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 as it stood in 1955.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal arises from a writ petition filed by the appellant Navnit Lal C. Javeri in the Bombay High Court in which he challenged the validity of section 12 1B  read with s. 2  6A   e  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922  No. 11 of 1922   hereinafter called the Act  as it stood in 1955.

facts.text: Bombay High Court rejected appellant's contention that the section is invalid.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has rejected the appellants companytention that the said section is invalid, and the appellant has companye to this Court with a certificate granted by the High Court.

facts.text: Appellant holds 11 out of 845 shares in Malegaon Electricity Co. Private Ltd., each share value Rs. 100.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant holds 11 out of 845 shares in a private limited companypany named the Malegaon Electricity Co.,  Private  Ltd.  hereinafter referred to as the companypany . The value of each share is Rs. 100.

facts.text: Company's business is to supply electricity to residents of Malegaon.

anchor.surface_text: The business of the companypany is to supply electricity to the residents of Malegaon.

facts.text: During 1955, appellant took a loan amounting to over Rs. 4 lakhs from the company.

anchor.surface_text: Some time during 1955, the appellant took a loan amounting to over Rs. 4 lakhs from the companypany.

facts.text: 8th Income-Tax Officer issued notice under s. 22(2) to appellant for assessment year 1956-57.

anchor.surface_text: A numberice was issued to the appellant by the 8th, Income-Tax Officer under s. 22  2  of the Act calling, upon him to make his return for the assessment year 1956-57.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer computed appellant's income at Rs. 3,58,460 including Rs. 2,83,126 as accumulated profits of company deemed dividend under s. 2(6A)(e).

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer companyputed his income at Rs. 3,58,460. This amount included a sum of Rs. 2,83,126 representing the accumulated profits of the companypany. The Income-tax Officer took the view that under s. 2  6A   e  the said amount must be deemed to be dividend received by the appellant,

facts.text: Appellant appealed to Appellate Assistant Commissioner, appeal dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: This order was challenged by the appellant by preferring an appeal before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner. The appeal, however, failed and was dismissed.

facts.text: Appellant preferred second appeal to Income Tax Appellate Tribunal, pending when writ filed.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then preferred a second appeal before the Income Tax Appellate Tribunal. Whilst this appeal was pending, before the said Tribunal, the appellant moved the High Court under Articles 226 and 227 of the Constitution,

facts.text: Sections 2(6A)(e) and 12(1B) introduced by Finance Act 15 of 1955, effective 1st April 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Both these provisions viz., s. 2 6A  e  and s. 12 lB  were introduced in the Act by the Finance Act 15 of 1955 which came into operation on the 1st of April, 1955.

facts.text: Central Board of Revenue issued circular No. 20 on 10th May 1955 assuring no tax if loans repaid before 30th June 1955.

anchor.surface_text: In order that the assurance given by the Minister in Parliament should be carried out, a circular No. 20 XXI-6 /55 was issued by the Central Board of Revenue on the 10th May, 1955.

facts.text: P.B. Gajendragadkar C.J. delivered majority judgment, Raghubar Dayal J. dissented.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgments of P. B. GAJENDRAGADKAR C.J., K. N. WANCHOO, HIDAYATULLAH and J. R. MUDHOLKAR JJ. was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR C.J. RAGHUBAR DAYAL J. delivered a dissenting Opinion.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal upholding constitutional validity of the sections.

anchor.surface_text: The result is, the appeal fails and is dismissed with companyts.

facts.text: Appellant's proportionate share in accumulated profits Rs. 2,83,126 would be Rs. 3,686 if distributed as dividend.

anchor.surface_text: He appellants share in the accumulated profits, if distributed as dividend would be 11/845the of Rs. 2,83,126 i.e., Rs. 3,686.

facts.text: Loan remained outstanding on first day of previous year relevant to assessment year 1955-56.

anchor.surface_text: if such loan or advance remained outstanding on the first day of such previous year.

facts.text: Company is private limited company not substantially interested by public within s.23A.

anchor.surface_text: private limited companypany named the Malegaon Electricity Co.,  Private  Ltd.

facts.text: Raghubar Dayal J. held sections void as beyond legislative competence under Entry 82.

anchor.surface_text: I am of opinion that the appeal should be allowed as ss. 12  1B  and 2  6A   e , of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, hereinafter called the Act, as they stood in 1955, are void.

facts.text: Minister for Revenue gave assurance in Parliament for exemption if loans refunded before 30th June 1955.

anchor.surface_text: the Honble Minister for Revenue Civil Expenditure save an assurance that outstanding loans and advances which are otherwise liable to be taxed as dividends in the assessment year 1955-56 will number be subjected to tax if it is shown that they had been genuinely refunded

holdings.text: the impugned section is not beyond the legislative competence of the legislature

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we are satisfied that the High Court was right in coming to the conclusion that the impugned section is not beyond the legislative competence of the legislature.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Liberal construction of 'income' under Entry 82 includes deemed income via fictions to prevent tax evasion; follows Navinchandra (capital gains), Sardar Baldev Singh (s.23A), Balaji (s.16(3)); rational connection as loans from controlled companies are evasion devices.

holdings.text: there is no scope for arguing that the fundamental rights of the shareholder under Art. 19 (1) (f) (g) have been contravened by the impugned provision

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, there is no scope for arguing that the fundamental rights of the shareholder under Art. 19 (1) (f) (g) have been contravened by the impugned provision. Therefore, we must reject Mr. Pathaks argument

holdings.reasoning_summary: No infringement of rights to property/trade; merely deems loan as dividend for tax; restriction reasonable given anti-evasion purpose and exemption for past genuine loans via circular.

holdings.text: There is obviously no scope for suggesting that the impugned provision contravenes Art. 14

anchor.surface_text: There is obviously no scope for suggesting that the impugned provision contravenes Art. 14 and in fact Mr. Pathak has not raised this point before us.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioner did not argue; no discrimination found; cites Madras HC upholding.

holdings.text: s. 12(1B) read with s. 2(6A)(e) was constitutionally valid

anchor.surface_text: That is how the only question which the High Court had to decide in the present writ proceedings was whether s. 12 (1B) read with s. 2 (6A) (e) was constitutionally valid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Upholds on legislative competence, Art.19, Art.14 grounds; integrates above holdings.

holdings.text: a circular of the kind which was issued by the Board would be binding on all officers and persons employed in the execution of the Act under s. 58 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: It is clear that a circular of the kind which was issued by the Board would be binding on all officers and persons employed in the execution of the Act under s. 58 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of s.58; supports reasonableness under Art.19 by exempting genuine past loans.

holdings.text: the appeal fails and is dismissed with costs

anchor.surface_text: The result is, the appeal fails and is dismissed with costs.

as observed by Gwyer C.J. in the United Provinces v. Atiqa Begum 1 . each general word should be held to extend to all ancillary or subsidiary matters which can fairly and reasonably be said to be comprehended in it. What the entries in the List purport to do is to confer legislative powers on the respective Legislatures in respect of areas or fields covered by the said entries-. and it is an elementary rule of construction that the widest possible construction must be put upon their words.

precedents.cited_proposition: entries in the Lists cannot be read in a narrow or restricted sense; general word should be held to extend to all ancillary or subsidiary matters

precedents.citation: Navinchandra Mafatlal v. The Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City 1

anchor.surface_text: In Navinchandra Mafatlal v. The Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City 1 , this Court had occasion to consider the question as to whether capital gains could be treated as income within the meaning of item 54 of List I of the Seventh Schedule to the Government of India Act, 1935.

precedents.case_name: Navinchandra Mafatlal v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City
precedents.cited_proposition: capital gains can be treated as income; words in constitutional enactment conferring legislative powers ought to be construed most liberally

precedents.citation: In re The Central Provinces and Berar Sales of Motor Spirit and Lubricants Taxation Act, 1938 No. 14 of 1938 1

anchor.surface_text: This aspect of the matter has also been clearly enunciated by Gwyer C.J. in In re The Central Provinces and Berar Sales of Motor Spirit and Lubricants Taxation Act, 1938 No. 14 of 1938 1 . I conceive, said the learned Chief Justice, that a broad and liberal spirit should inspire those whose duty it is to interpret it  the Constitution  but I do number imply by this that they are free to stretch or pervert the language of the enactment in the interests of any legal or constitutional theory, or even for the purpose of supplying omissions or of correcting supposed errors.

precedents.case_name: In re Central Provinces and Berar Sales of Motor Spirit and Lubricants Taxation Act
precedents.cited_proposition: broad and liberal spirit in interpreting Constitution but not stretching language

precedents.citation: Sardar Baldev Singh v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Delhi Ajmer 1

anchor.surface_text: The next decision to which we ought to refer deals with s. 23A of the Act. In Sardar Baldev Singh v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Delhi Ajmer 1  the validity of the said section was challenged.

precedents.case_name: Sardar Baldev Singh v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Delhi Ajmer
precedents.cited_proposition: validity of s.23A upheld; prevents evasion of tax by deeming undistributed profits as dividends
precedents.cited_holding: s.23A constitutionally valid as anti-avoidance measure

precedents.case_name: Balaji v. Income-tax Officer, Special Investigation Circle
precedents.cited_proposition: s.16(3)(a)(i)(ii) valid as prevents evasion; widest import to entries

precedents.citation: K. M. S. Lakshmana Aiyar v. Additional Income-tax Officer, Special Circle, Madras, 1

anchor.surface_text: There is obviously no scope for suggesting that the impugned provision contravenes Art. 14 and in fact Mr. Pathak has not raised this point before us. In that connection, he himself fairly invited our attention to the decision of the Madras High Court in K. M. S. Lakshmana Aiyar v. Additional Income-tax Officer, Special Circle, Madras, 1  where the challenge to the validity of the impugned section on the ground that it contravened Art. 14 has been repelled.

precedents.case_name: K. M. S. Lakshmana Aiyar v. Additional Income-tax Officer, Special Circle, Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: impugned section does not contravene Art.14

precedents.citation: Navinchandra Mafatlal v. The Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City 1

anchor.surface_text: In Navinchandra Mafatlal v. The Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City 1  this Court had to consider the content of the word income as used in Entry 54, List 1, Seventh Schedule to the Government of India Act, 1935  which is identical with Entry 82. List 1, Seventh Schedule to the Constitution , in determining whether the imposition of a tax under the head capital gains by the Central Legislature, was ultra vires.

precedents.case_name: Navinchandra Mafatlal v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City
precedents.cited_proposition: income includes capital gains; natural meaning 'a thing that comes in'

anchor.surface_text: In the United States, the word income was first defined in Strattons Independence v. Howhert 3  decided on December 1, 1913, as gain derived from capital, from labour, or from both combined.

precedents.cited_proposition: income as gain derived from capital, labour or both

anchor.surface_text: In Eisner v. Macomber 1  referred to by this Court in Mafatlals case 1 , the court had to construe the word income as used in the XVI Amendment of the Constitution of the United States, which is The Congress shall have power to lay and collect taxes on incomes, from whatever source derived, without apportionment among the several States, and without regard to any census or enumeration.

precedents.cited_proposition: definition of income as gain derived from capital, labour or both combined; stock dividend not income
precedents.cited_holding: income may be defined as the gain derived from capital, from labor, or from both combined

precedents.citation: Resch v. The Federal Commissioner of Taxation 1

anchor.surface_text: The question in the Australian case viz., Resch v. The Federal Commissioner of Taxation 1  was about the validity of the provisions in the income-tax legislation to the effect that distribution of profits in the course of winding-up of a company would be treated on the same footing as the distribution by the company as a going concern.

precedents.case_name: Resch v. Federal Commissioner of Taxation
precedents.cited_proposition: profits in winding up treated as income; wide power to tax all profits and gains
